fool-hero.justification: Demonstrates immense supernatural capability, controlling the elements (thunder, lightning, rain) and possessing clear, purposeful intent (meeting Macbeth).

angel-demon.justification: Explicitly an agent of moral corruption and chaos, dedicated to inverting natural order ('Fair is foul'). Highly dangerous and depraved.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Highly unpredictable and unconventional, operating outside of social and natural laws. Their language (rhyme, paradox) is creative and disruptive.

fool-hero.justification: Shares the collective supernatural power and foresight of the Weird Sisters, demonstrating capability in planning and prophecy.

angel-demon.justification: Contributes to the atmosphere of moral inversion and chaos, confirming the dangerous nature of their meeting and purpose.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Part of the unconventional group, focused on disrupting the predictable outcome of the battle ('When the battle's lost and won').

fool-hero.justification: Shares the collective supernatural power and foresight, demonstrating capability by setting the precise time and target for their meeting.

angel-demon.justification: Confirms the corrupting target of their meeting ('There to meet with Macbeth'), solidifying their role as agents of darkness.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Part of the unconventional group, focused on disrupting the established order through unpredictable means.

evt_1.title: Plan meeting
evt_1.description: The three witches collectively discuss and decide upon the time ('When the battle's lost and won') and place ('Upon the heath') for their next meeting.

evt_2.title: Target Macbeth
evt_2.description: The witches conclude their planning by identifying the object of their meeting: 'There to meet with Macbeth.' The collective (Many) directs their future action toward a single entity (One).

evt_3.title: Chant theme
evt_3.description: All three witches act in unison (as 'ALL') to chant the paradoxical theme 'Fair is foul, and foul is fair,' establishing the supernatural and moral ambiguity of the play.

fool-hero.justification: Holds ultimate political power and authority (Hero), capable of judgment and command, but relies entirely on others for physical defense and was previously deceived by Cawdor (Fool).

angel-demon.justification: The embodiment of virtuous, legitimate rule. Dispenses justice and honor, showing kindness and appreciation ('smack of honour').

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Upholds the established hierarchy and order. All actions (rewarding, punishing) are serious and predictable according to royal protocol.

fool-hero.justification: Competent prince, capable of identifying and addressing the Sergeant, demonstrating awareness and respect, though not the primary actor in the scene.

angel-demon.justification: Loyal son and prince, concerned for the welfare of the soldiers who protected him ('Hail, brave friend!').

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Adheres strictly to court protocol and military respect, reinforcing the established order.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable soldier who fought bravely ('hardy soldier'), demonstrating high competence. However, he is currently physically weak and wounded ('faint, my gashes cry for help').

angel-demon.justification: Fought for the King and justice, displaying loyalty and honor, which Duncan explicitly recognizes.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His role is traditional (soldier/messenger), but his language is highly creative, dramatic, and unpredictable, using elaborate, almost poetic metaphors to describe the battle ('spent swimmers,' 'cannons overcharged').

fool-hero.justification: Highly competent Thane and effective messenger, capable of delivering complex military and political news accurately and efficiently.

angel-demon.justification: A loyal agent of the King, focused on reporting victory and justice against traitors.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Strictly adheres to protocol, delivering official titles and news, reinforcing the established hierarchy and the consequences of treason.

fool-hero.justification: Competent courtier and observer, capable of interpreting Ross's demeanor, but plays a minimal role in the action.

angel-demon.justification: Loyal courtier present to witness and support the King.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Engages in standard, predictable court behavior.

fool-hero.justification: Described as having superhuman capability, valor, and purpose ('brave Macbeth,' 'valour's minion'), demonstrating extreme competence and power in battle.

angel-demon.justification: Currently viewed as the epitome of loyalty and virtue, whose extreme violence is sanctioned and directed toward justice and the defense of the realm.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His actions serve the established order (Traditionalist), but the sheer, excessive, and creative brutality of his fighting ('unseam'd him from the nave to the chaps') introduces an element of unpredictable extremity (Adventurer).

fool-hero.justification: Initially capable of leading a revolt, but ultimately proven incompetent and weak against Macbeth, resulting in his humiliating defeat and death ('faced the slave').

angel-demon.justification: Described as 'merciless,' a 'rebel,' and swarming with 'multiplying villanies of nature.' Pure corruption and treason.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His entire existence in the scene is defined by his revolutionary act of rebellion against the established political order.

fool-hero.justification: Capable enough to assist the enemy and lead a conflict, but ultimately failed and was easily exposed and condemned by the King.

angel-demon.justification: The 'most disloyal traitor' who deceived the King's 'bosom interest.' Pure corruption.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Engaged in treason and rebellion, seeking to disrupt the traditional political structure.

evt_1.title: Request report
evt_1.description: Malcolm greets the wounded Sergeant and asks him to 'Say to the king the knowledge of the broil / As thou didst leave it.'

evt_2.title: Report victory
evt_2.description: The Sergeant delivers the first part of his report, detailing the initial stalemate and Macbeth's heroic action in slaying the rebel Macdonwald.

evt_3.title: Report counter-attack
evt_3.description: The Sergeant continues his report, describing the immediate second assault by the Norweyan lord and the fierce, successful defense mounted by Macbeth and Banquo.

evt_4.title: Order medical aid
evt_4.description: Recognizing the Sergeant's wounds, Duncan praises him and orders attendants to 'Go get him surgeons.'

evt_5.title: Report treason and victory
evt_5.description: Ross arrives and reports the final conclusion of the war, specifically naming the Thane of Cawdor as a 'disloyal traitor' who assisted Norway, and confirming that Macbeth secured the ultimate victory.

evt_6.title: Order execution
evt_6.description: Based on Ross's report of treason, Duncan orders the immediate death of the Thane of Cawdor: 'go pronounce his present death.'

evt_7.title: Bestow title
evt_7.description: Duncan rewards Macbeth for his valor by commanding that he be greeted 'with his former title' (Thane of Cawdor).

evt_8.title: Accept mission
evt_8.description: Ross accepts the King's command to oversee the execution of Cawdor and the transfer of the title to Macbeth: 'I'll see it done.'

fool-hero.justification: Demonstrates high innate potency by controlling natural forces (winds) and possessing powerful, accurate prophetic knowledge. Highly capable in malice.

angel-demon.justification: Explicitly malicious and corrupt, focused on petty cruelty and the destruction of others ('I'll do, I'll do, and I'll do').

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Highly unpredictable and creative in her methods (sailing in a sieve, using spells and rhymes) to disrupt established order.

fool-hero.justification: Shares the collective supernatural power of the Weird Sisters, contributing to the control of the elements and the delivery of prophecy.

angel-demon.justification: Engages in dark acts ('Killing swine') and contributes to the corrupting prophecies, aligning fully with the demonic orientation.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Part of the unconventional, chaotic group that uses creative language and methods to introduce instability.

fool-hero.justification: Shares the collective supernatural power and delivers the most potent and destabilizing prophecy ('thou shalt be king hereafter!').

angel-demon.justification: Delivers the ultimate corrupting promise, directly tempting Macbeth toward regicide.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Part of the chaotic group, focused on introducing radical, unpredictable change into the political structure.

fool-hero.justification: High innate potency (proven warrior, Thane), but demonstrates immediate internal incompetence and paralysis ('function is smother'd in surmise') when faced with the moral choice, reducing his effective Hero score.

angel-demon.justification: Starts loyal (Angel), but his internal monologue is dominated by the 'horrid image' of murder and ambition, showing a rapid and profound shift toward corruption (Demon).

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His current status is Traditionalist, but his entire focus in the scene shifts to the highly unpredictable, revolutionary act of seizing the crown (Adventurer).

fool-hero.justification: A capable warrior who demonstrates high intellectual capability and moral strength by resisting temptation and providing clear-headed warnings.

angel-demon.justification: Acts as the moral compass, recognizing the Witches as 'instruments of darkness' and remaining loyal and cautious, representing virtue.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Highly focused on established order, reality, and duty. He warns against the unpredictable and chaotic nature of the prophecies.

fool-hero.justification: Competent and effective messenger, capable of delivering official news and honors accurately, but lacks independent power.

angel-demon.justification: An agent of the King, representing the virtuous, legitimate social order and delivering deserved praise.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Strictly adheres to protocol, reinforcing the established hierarchy and the predictable flow of royal honors.

fool-hero.justification: Competent and effective messenger, capable of explaining the complex political and legal reasons for the former Thane's downfall.

angel-demon.justification: An agent of the King, focused on justice and explaining the consequences of treason, upholding the moral law.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Strictly adheres to protocol, reinforcing the established hierarchy and the predictable consequences of breaking the law.

evt_1.title: Plan torment
evt_1.description: The First Witch details her plan to torment the sailor (master o' the Tiger) for nine times nine weeks, and the Second and Third Witches contribute by offering winds to aid the curse.

evt_2.title: Perform ritual
evt_2.description: The Witches (acting as 'ALL') join hands and perform a collective chant and dance ('go about, about') to finalize their charm before Macbeth arrives.

evt_3.title: Deliver prophecy
evt_3.description: The three Witches collectively hail Macbeth with three titles: Thane of Glamis, Thane of Cawdor, and King hereafter.

evt_4.title: Deliver prophecy
evt_4.description: After being challenged by Banquo, the Witches deliver a paradoxical prophecy concerning his future, stating he will be father to kings.

evt_5.title: Vanish
evt_5.description: The Witches disappear into the air after Macbeth demands they speak further, leaving Macbeth and Banquo confused.

evt_6.title: Bestow title
evt_6.description: Ross, acting on behalf of King Duncan, greets Macbeth with the title 'thane of Cawdor,' confirming the second prophecy.

evt_7.title: Explain treason
evt_7.description: Angus explains that the former Thane of Cawdor was executed for 'treasons capital, confess'd and proved,' justifying the transfer of the title to Macbeth.

evt_8.title: Test ambition
evt_8.description: Macbeth immediately questions Banquo about whether he now hopes his children will be kings, testing Banquo's reaction to the confirmed prophecy.

evt_9.title: Warn against deceit
evt_9.description: Banquo warns Macbeth that 'the instruments of darkness tell us truths' to 'betray's in deepest consequence,' cautioning him against trusting the Witches.

evt_10.title: Contemplate regicide
evt_10.description: In an extended aside, Macbeth struggles internally with the 'horrid image' of murdering Duncan to achieve the final prophecy, concluding he might let 'chance may crown me, Without my stir.'

evt_11.title: Propose future discussion
evt_11.description: Macbeth apologizes for his distraction and proposes that he and Banquo discuss the strange events ('what hath chanced') privately at a later time.

fool-hero.justification: Holds the ultimate power (Hero 60), but demonstrates significant incompetence and poor judgment by trusting the former Cawdor absolutely and failing to perceive the danger in Macbeth (Fool 40). His generosity is politically naive.

angel-demon.justification: Represents pure, overflowing virtue, gratitude, and benevolence. He is the moral center of the kingdom.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Highly focused on maintaining the established order, rewarding loyalty, and adhering to dynastic tradition by naming Malcolm the Prince of Cumberland.

fool-hero.justification: Capable and articulate in his official duties (reporting the execution). His new title, Prince of Cumberland, grants him high political potency and purpose.

angel-demon.justification: Loyal son and servant of the state, delivering truthful and virtuous reports.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Adheres to protocol and is the recipient of a traditional, dynastic honor, reinforcing the status quo.

fool-hero.justification: Possesses immense innate potency (proven warrior, capable of decisive action). His intelligence is immediately focused on solving the problem of Malcolm's succession.

angel-demon.justification: Publicly speaks words of loyalty (Angel), but his internal monologue ('black and deep desires,' 'Stars, hide your fires') reveals a complete, immediate commitment to corruption and regicide (Demon).

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His public role is Traditionalist, but his internal decision to 'o'erleap' the Prince of Cumberland is a radical, unpredictable, and revolutionary act of Adventurism against the established order.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable warrior (praised by Duncan) who demonstrates intellectual strength and moral clarity in his responses.

angel-demon.justification: Humble, loyal, and virtuous. His response affirms his duty to the King and the natural order ('The harvest is your own').

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Focused entirely on duty, loyalty, and the established hierarchy, using predictable, serious language.

fool-hero.justification: Competent Thanes and members of the court, capable of fulfilling their roles and attending the King.

angel-demon.justification: Represent the loyal, virtuous nobility supporting the King and the social order.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Adhere strictly to court protocol and hierarchy, reinforcing the traditional structure of the kingdom.

evt_1.title: Report execution status
evt_1.description: Malcolm reports to Duncan the details of the former Thane of Cawdor's execution, noting his confession and noble death.

evt_2.title: Express gratitude
evt_2.description: Duncan greets Macbeth and expresses overwhelming gratitude for his service, stating that no reward can match his merit.

evt_3.title: Pledge service
evt_3.description: Macbeth responds humbly, stating that his service and loyalty are merely his duty and are their own reward.

evt_4.title: Promise advancement
evt_4.description: Duncan promises to nurture Macbeth's success, using the metaphor: 'I have begun to plant thee, and will labour / To make thee full of growing.'

evt_5.title: Acknowledge merit
evt_5.description: Duncan acknowledges Banquo's equal merit and embraces him, holding him to his heart.

evt_6.title: Name successor
evt_6.description: Duncan publicly announces that his eldest son, Malcolm, will be named the Prince of Cumberland, establishing him as the heir apparent.

evt_7.title: Command travel
evt_7.description: Duncan commands the court to travel from the current location 'From hence to Inverness' (Macbeth's castle).

evt_8.title: Volunteer service
evt_8.description: Macbeth volunteers to ride ahead of the King to act as a 'harbinger' and prepare his wife for the royal visit.

evt_9.title: Resolve obstacle
evt_9.description: In an aside, Macbeth recognizes Malcolm (the Prince of Cumberland) as a major obstacle to the throne, resolving that he must either 'fall down, or else o'erleap' this step, and hides his 'black and deep desires.'

fool-hero.justification: Demonstrates extreme capability, intelligence, and powerful willpower. She immediately formulates a complex, high-stakes plan and resolves to manipulate Macbeth, showing no incompetence.

angel-demon.justification: Actively rejects virtue ('milk of human kindness') and explicitly invokes demonic forces ('unsex me here,' 'murdering ministers') to fill her with 'direst cruelty' for the purpose of regicide.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Her entire focus is on revolutionary change, overthrowing the established order, and using highly creative, unpredictable methods of deception ('look like the innocent flower, but be the serpent under't').

fool-hero.justification: Possesses high innate potency (proven warrior, Thane), but Lady Macbeth identifies a critical internal weakness (Foolishness) in his moral resolve and willingness to act decisively ('too full o' the milk of human kindness').

angel-demon.justification: Lady Macbeth notes his current inclination toward Angelic behavior ('wouldst thou holily, wouldst not play false'), but his ambition and presence in the scene indicate he is already heavily tempted by the Demon pole.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His established role is Traditionalist, but his ambition (fueled by the prophecy) pushes him toward the highly unpredictable, revolutionary path of the Adventurer, which Lady Macbeth encourages.

fool-hero.justification: Competent and effective in his duty, delivering crucial news accurately and quickly, despite the difficulty of the journey.

angel-demon.justification: A functional agent of the King and Thane, representing the virtuous social order and delivering factual, non-corrupting information.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Strictly adheres to protocol and duty, reinforcing the established hierarchy through his function.

fool-hero.justification: Possess supernatural power and 'more than mortal knowledge,' demonstrating high capability to influence fate and vanish into 'air.'

angel-demon.justification: The source of the corrupting ambition and the metaphysical aid that leads to evil. They are agents of darkness.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Highly unpredictable, dealing in chaos and disrupting the natural and political order through prophecy.

fool-hero.justification: The King, possessing ultimate political and military power (Hero). His vulnerability stems from his trust, not his innate capability.

angel-demon.justification: Represents the virtuous, divinely sanctioned social order, hospitality, and justice. The target of the Demon's plot.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: The ultimate symbol of the fixed, predictable, and established hierarchy of the state.

fool-hero.justification: Supernatural entities capable of altering human nature and aiding in 'mortal thoughts,' demonstrating high metaphysical power.

angel-demon.justification: Explicitly called upon as 'murdering ministers' to replace 'milk for gall' and fill Lady Macbeth with 'direst cruelty.' Purely corrupting forces.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Agents of chaos and disruption, aiding in the overthrow of natural law and social order.

evt_1.title: Deliver information
evt_1.description: Lady Macbeth reads Macbeth's letter, which informs her of the witches' prophecies (Thane of Cawdor, King hereafter) and his desire to share the news of his promised greatness.

evt_2.title: Resolve manipulation
evt_2.description: Lady Macbeth analyzes Macbeth's 'milk of human kindness' and resolves internally to use her persuasive power ('pour my spirits in thine ear') to chastise him into taking the crown.

evt_3.title: Deliver news
evt_3.description: The Messenger delivers the critical, unexpected news that King Duncan is arriving at the castle that very night.

evt_4.title: Invoke transformation
evt_4.description: Lady Macbeth calls upon the supernatural entities ('spirits,' 'murdering ministers,' 'thick night') to 'unsex' her, fill her with cruelty, and conceal the impending murder.

evt_5.title: Inform schedule
evt_5.description: Macbeth confirms Duncan's arrival and states that the King plans to leave 'To-morrow'.

evt_6.title: Instruct concealment
evt_6.description: Lady Macbeth instructs Macbeth to hide his murderous intent by appearing innocent: 'look like the innocent flower, But be the serpent under't.'

evt_7.title: Seize control
evt_7.description: Lady Macbeth asserts dominance over the plan, telling Macbeth to put 'This night's great business into my dispatch,' ensuring she controls the execution of the regicide.

evt_8.title: Defer discussion
evt_8.description: Macbeth briefly responds to Lady Macbeth's intense planning by saying, 'We will speak further,' deferring the final decision.

fool-hero.justification: Holds the highest political status (Hero), but demonstrates extreme incompetence and weakness in judgment and situational awareness, failing to perceive the mortal danger or the false nature of Lady Macbeth's welcome (Fool).

angel-demon.justification: Embodies pure virtue, generosity, and trust. He is the representation of the safe, moral order being threatened.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: The ultimate symbol of established hierarchy, protocol, and tradition. His language is formal and focused on duty and grace.

fool-hero.justification: A capable and intelligent observer. His detailed, poetic description of the castle's air demonstrates intellectual capacity and awareness, though he shares Duncan's lack of suspicion regarding the hosts.

angel-demon.justification: Loyal, virtuous, and focused on the natural beauty and safety of the environment, acting as a moral companion to the King.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Focused on established order and loyalty. His observations are serious and reflective, reinforcing the pleasantness of the traditional setting.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable, intelligent, and purposeful in executing her role as the deceptive hostess. Her flattery is calculated and effective.

angel-demon.justification: Profoundly corrupt and depraved, masking murderous intent and betrayal of hospitality with excessive, false humility and service.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: While her outward behavior uses traditional language of service, her underlying intent (regicide) is the ultimate unpredictable, revolutionary act against the established order.

fool-hero.justification: Possesses high innate potency (Hero), but is internally paralyzed by indecision and moral conflict in Scene 7, demonstrating a lack of immediate purpose and resolve (Fool).

angel-demon.justification: Struggles with the moral duty (Angel) but is dominated by the contemplation of the 'bloody instruction' and regicide (Demon).

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His contemplation is focused on breaking every traditional bond (kinsman, subject, host) to pursue a radical, unpredictable, and revolutionary path to power.

fool-hero.justification: A collective group demonstrating competence and capability in their specific duties of service and managing the feast.

angel-demon.justification: Performing the virtuous and expected duties of hospitality and service for a royal guest.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Their entire function is based on strict adherence to protocol, routine, and predictable service for the royal court.

evt_1.title: Greet hostess
evt_1.description: Upon Lady Macbeth's entrance, Duncan formally greets her as 'our honour'd hostess' and explains that the trouble of hosting him is a form of love.

evt_2.title: Profess loyalty
evt_2.description: Lady Macbeth responds with extreme flattery and humility, stating that all their service is inadequate compared to the 'honours deep and broad' Duncan has bestowed, declaring they are his eternally indebted servants ('hermits').

evt_3.title: Inquire about host
evt_3.description: Duncan asks Lady Macbeth about the whereabouts of Macbeth ('the thane of Cawdor'), explaining that Macbeth's 'great love' allowed him to ride ahead.

evt_4.title: Offer resources
evt_4.description: Lady Macbeth continues her performance of subservience, assuring Duncan that all their possessions are held 'in compt' (in trust) for his highness's pleasure.

evt_5.title: Request escort
evt_5.description: Duncan asks Lady Macbeth to take his hand and 'Conduct me to mine host,' concluding the formal greeting and setting the stage for the night.

fool-hero.justification: Demonstrates high intellectual capability (Hero) in analyzing the moral and practical consequences of the murder, but exhibits profound psychological weakness and indecision (Fool). He is easily manipulated and shamed by his wife, showing a lack of internal resolve until the very end.

angel-demon.justification: Starts by attempting to retreat to an Angelic position, recognizing duty and Duncan's virtue. However, his 'vaulting ambition' and ultimate submission to the murder plot confirm his commitment to the corrupt, Demonic path by the scene's conclusion.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His arguments against the murder are based on traditional duty and honor. However, the act he ultimately agrees to—regicide—is the ultimate unpredictable, revolutionary, and creative disruption of the established order (Adventurer).

fool-hero.justification: Exhibits extreme capability, purposefulness, and intelligence. She is a master strategist and manipulator, instantly countering all of Macbeth's objections and providing a detailed, actionable plan.

angel-demon.justification: She is the embodiment of corruption in this scene, actively rejecting all moral constraints, mocking virtue, and using extreme, depraved imagery (the infanticide metaphor) to achieve her dangerous, arrogant goal.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Highly creative in her psychological warfare and her detailed, unconventional plan to frame the guards. She is entirely focused on radical change and the overthrow of the traditional hierarchy.

evt_1.title: Debate morality
evt_1.description: In a soliloquy, Macbeth weighs the moral and practical consequences of murdering Duncan, concluding that justice will 'plague the inventor' and that he lacks the motivation ('no spur') except for 'vaulting ambition'.

evt_2.title: Withdraw commitment
evt_2.description: Macbeth informs Lady Macbeth that he has decided to abandon the plan to murder Duncan, citing the recent honors bestowed upon him by the King.

evt_3.title: Shame and manipulate
evt_3.description: Lady Macbeth launches a fierce verbal attack, questioning Macbeth's manhood, calling his love into question, and using the shocking hypothetical image of murdering her own child to shame him into resuming the plan.

evt_4.title: Propose murder strategy
evt_4.description: In response to Macbeth's doubt ('If we should fail?'), Lady Macbeth outlines a detailed, practical plan: getting Duncan's chamberlains drunk, using their daggers to kill Duncan, and framing the guards.

evt_5.title: Commit to regicide
evt_5.description: Convinced by Lady Macbeth's plan and resolve, Macbeth declares, 'I am settled,' and resolves internally to proceed with the 'terrible feat' of murdering Duncan.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable (implied warrior status) and demonstrates strong internal potency by actively fighting against the 'cursed thoughts' and maintaining vigilance ('Give me my sword').

angel-demon.justification: Acts as the moral compass, praying for divine restraint and explicitly stating his commitment to keeping his 'bosom franchised and allegiance clear,' resisting Macbeth's implied corruption.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Focused on duty, protocol (reporting the King's pleasure), and maintaining the established order. He is serious and cautious about the supernatural and change.

fool-hero.justification: Neutral capability; competent enough to observe the time and follow his father, but lacks independent agency or power in this scene.

angel-demon.justification: Represents innocence and obedience, acting as a pure, safe presence in contrast to the surrounding darkness.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Entirely subordinate and predictable, adhering strictly to the routine of the night and his father's instructions.

fool-hero.justification: High innate potency (Hero) demonstrated by his resolve to act, but currently suffering from severe internal paralysis and mental incompetence (Fool) due to guilt and hallucination ('A dagger of the mind').

angel-demon.justification: His actions and thoughts are entirely focused on the ultimate act of corruption (regicide). The soliloquy is a full descent into demonic imagery and murderous intent, suppressing all residual virtue.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Engaging in the most radical, unpredictable, and revolutionary act possible (killing the King). His internal monologue is highly creative and imaginative (the vision of the dagger), marking him as an extreme Adventurer.

fool-hero.justification: Competent in their limited role (carrying a torch, receiving and executing instructions), but lacking high agency.

angel-demon.justification: Morally neutral, defined by obedience (Angel), but proximity to Macbeth's immediate evil and facilitation of the murder preparations (the bell signal) introduces a slight shadow (Demon).

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: The epitome of routine and adherence to established hierarchy and duty, making them highly predictable.

evt_1.title: Deliver gift
evt_1.description: Banquo, acting as an intermediary for Duncan, presents Macbeth with a diamond intended for Lady Macbeth as a token of the King's gratitude for their hospitality.

evt_2.title: Resist temptation
evt_2.description: Banquo prays to 'merciful powers' to restrain the 'cursed thoughts' (related to the witches' prophecies) that trouble him before sleep, establishing his moral integrity.

evt_3.title: Propose meeting
evt_3.description: Macbeth suggests that he and Banquo should meet later to discuss the matter of the 'three weird sisters' prophecies.

evt_4.title: Offer alliance
evt_4.description: Macbeth makes a veiled offer of honor and advancement to Banquo if he agrees to 'cleave to my consent' when the time comes.

evt_5.title: Refuse treason
evt_5.description: Banquo accepts the offer only on the condition that he loses none of his honor and keeps his 'allegiance clear' (to King Duncan), effectively refusing to participate in any treasonous plot.

evt_6.title: Issue command
evt_6.description: Macbeth instructs the Servant to tell Lady Macbeth to ring the bell when his drink is ready, setting up the prearranged signal for the murder.

evt_7.title: Hallucinate/Visualize intent
evt_7.description: Macbeth experiences a vivid hallucination of a bloody dagger, which he recognizes as a manifestation of his murderous intent ('A dagger of the mind').

evt_8.title: Receive signal
evt_8.description: The bell rings (initiated by Lady Macbeth offstage), which Macbeth interprets as the signal to proceed with the murder of Duncan.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable and purposeful. She successfully executes the initial plan (drugging the grooms) and demonstrates superior mental fortitude by taking immediate, decisive action to correct Macbeth's failure (retrieving the daggers and framing the guards), calling him 'Infirm of purpose!'

angel-demon.justification: The primary instigator and facilitator of regicide. She is utterly ruthless, dismissing moral consequences ('A little water clears us of this deed') and actively engaging in corruption and deceit.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: She is actively breaking all social and moral traditions (regicide, hospitality). Her actions are highly unpredictable and require creative, quick thinking to manage the crisis and fabricate the cover story ('I'll gild the faces of the grooms withal').

fool-hero.justification: While he performed the physical deed (Hero), his immediate psychological collapse renders him incompetent and paralyzed. He is unable to follow through on the plan, cannot think clearly, and is easily manipulated, demonstrating a complete failure of internal purpose.

angel-demon.justification: He has committed the ultimate Demon act (regicide). Although his intense guilt and inability to say 'Amen' show a struggling conscience, the completed act of corruption defines his alignment in this moment.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: The act of regicide is highly Adventurous (revolutionary break from tradition). However, his subsequent behavior is not creative chaos but a serious, predictable psychological breakdown rooted in traditional moral fear and religious anxiety (the voice crying 'Sleep no more!').

fool-hero.justification: Completely incapacitated, drugged, and unconscious. They are utterly powerless and unable to perform their duty, serving only as props for the crime.

angel-demon.justification: They are innocent victims of the plot, framed for a crime they did not commit. They represent the virtuous, unsuspecting social order that is being corrupted.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Their role is strictly defined (attendants/guards). Their state is passive and predictable (sleeping), reinforcing the established order that Lady Macbeth seeks to exploit.

evt_1.title: Demand entry
evt_1.description: The repeated knocking (implied to be Macduff and Lennox) forces the Porter to wake up and eventually open the gate.

evt_2.title: Amuse self
evt_2.description: The Porter engages in a lengthy, self-directed comic monologue, imagining himself as the gatekeeper of hell.

evt_3.title: Open gate
evt_3.description: The Porter physically opens the gate, allowing Macduff and Lennox to enter the castle.

evt_4.title: Offer guidance
evt_4.description: Macbeth offers to lead Macduff to Duncan's chamber, fulfilling Macduff's duty.

evt_5.title: Describe omens
evt_5.description: Lennox recounts the terrible, unnatural events of the previous night (storms, screams, shaking earth), establishing the supernatural context for the murder.

evt_6.title: Announce murder
evt_6.description: Macduff returns from the King's chamber and announces the discovery of Duncan's murder ('O horror, horror, horror!').

evt_7.title: Direct viewing
evt_7.description: Macduff commands Macbeth and Lennox to go see the sight for themselves ('Approach the chamber... See, and then speak yourselves').

evt_8.title: Raise alarm
evt_8.description: Macduff rings the alarum-bell and calls out to the sleeping members of the household (Banquo, Malcolm, Donalbain) to wake them to the treason.

evt_9.title: Inform
evt_9.description: Macduff explicitly tells the princes that their royal father has been murdered.

evt_10.title: Accuse
evt_10.description: Lennox presents the evidence suggesting the chamberlains committed the murder.

evt_11.title: Confess murder
evt_11.description: Macbeth admits to killing the chamberlains out of 'fury' and 'violent love' for Duncan, a critical move to eliminate witnesses.

evt_12.title: Challenge action
evt_12.description: Macduff immediately questions Macbeth's justification for killing the guards ('Wherefore did you so?').

evt_13.title: Feign illness
evt_13.description: Lady Macbeth cries out for help and faints, successfully diverting attention away from Macbeth's suspicious confession.

evt_14.title: Propose investigation
evt_14.description: Banquo calls for the lords to meet and question the murder, vowing to fight the 'undivulged pretence' of treason.

evt_15.title: Affirm unity
evt_15.description: The lords collectively agree to Banquo's proposal and Macbeth's subsequent call to meet in the hall, establishing a temporary, false unity.

evt_16.title: Propose flight
evt_16.description: Malcolm, speaking aside, suggests they must flee the castle immediately, suspecting danger.

evt_17.title: Plan separation
evt_17.description: Donalbain agrees to flee and suggests they separate (he to Ireland, Malcolm to England) to ensure their safety, thus removing the rightful heirs from the scene.

fool-hero.justification: Incompetent in his duty (drunk, slow to open the gate). His capability is limited to rambling, vulgar humor rather than effective action.

angel-demon.justification: Explicitly associates himself with 'hell-gate' and 'Beelzebub,' focusing his monologue on various forms of sin (lechery, treason, greed). His orientation is toward the corrupt and low aspects of life.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Highly unpredictable, using creative, rambling, and humorous wordplay (the equivocator speech) to disrupt the serious tone of the scene.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable and purposeful (sent by the King). Demonstrates immense rhetorical power and takes immediate, decisive action to raise the alarm and rally the nobles.

angel-demon.justification: The voice of pure loyalty and virtue. He frames the murder as 'sacrilegious' and the violation of 'The Lord's anointed temple,' positioning himself against the treasonous malice.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Driven entirely by duty, protocol ('my limited service'), and the need to restore the established moral and political order. Highly serious and predictable in his righteous horror.

fool-hero.justification: Competent noble, capable of perceptive observation and articulate reporting of the terrifying, unnatural omens of the night.

angel-demon.justification: Aligned with the virtuous order, concerned with the moral implications of the chaos and the unnatural events.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Serious and focused on interpreting events within a traditional, cosmological framework (omens reflecting the state of the kingdom).

fool-hero.justification: Capable of decisive action (killing the grooms) and highly effective rhetorical performance, but his internal state is one of panic and deception, limiting his true heroic potency.

angel-demon.justification: The active murderer and source of corruption. He attempts to project Angelic grief, but his actions (lying, killing witnesses) are purely Demon-aligned.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His crime forces him onto a revolutionary, unpredictable path. He must improvise and use creative, flowery language to mask his treason, breaking all traditional bonds.

fool-hero.justification: Demonstrates immediate presence of mind and control upon entering, quickly attempting to manage the situation. Her fainting spell is a powerful, manipulative tactic.

angel-demon.justification: Deeply corrupt and complicit in the murder. Her attempt to play the 'gentle lady' is a calculated deception to deflect suspicion.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Her actions are theatrical, calculated, and highly unconventional (fainting) to disrupt the investigation and protect the secret.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable, rational, and decisive. He focuses on practical steps (attending to the lady) and then calls for a formal, organized investigation.

angel-demon.justification: The moral anchor. He aligns himself with God and vows to fight 'Against the undivulged pretence I fight / Of treasonous malice.'

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Insists on following established protocol and legal/moral procedures to investigate the crime and restore order.

fool-hero.justification: Demonstrates high intellectual capability and foresight by immediately recognizing the danger and formulating a pragmatic, self-preserving plan to flee.

angel-demon.justification: Rightful heir and loyal son, but his immediate focus is survival, which requires temporary withdrawal from the moral fight.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His decision to flee to England is a radical, unpredictable move that breaks the traditional expectation of the heir staying to mourn or fight, prioritizing a creative solution for survival.

fool-hero.justification: Shows high capability in assessing the immediate, hidden threat ('daggers in men's smiles') and articulating the need for separation to ensure survival.

angel-demon.justification: Aligned with virtue, but focused on survival against the hidden Demon forces. His suspicion is a necessary defense.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His decision to flee to Ireland, separate from his brother, is a highly unconventional and unpredictable move, prioritizing safety over traditional mourning rites.

fool-hero.justification: Assumed competence as a Thane/noble, though he has no lines in this section, he is present and participates in the collective agreement.

angel-demon.justification: Aligns with the loyal nobles (Banquo, Macduff) against the treason.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Follows the lead of the loyal nobles to put on 'manly readiness' and meet in the hall, adhering to traditional duty.

evt_1.title: Discuss consequences
evt_1.description: The Old Man and Ross exchange observations about the unnatural events (darkness, strange animal behavior) that have followed Duncan's murder, establishing the theme of cosmic disorder.

evt_2.title: Inquire about murderer
evt_2.description: Ross asks Macduff directly, 'Is't known who did this more than bloody deed?'

evt_3.title: Implicate heirs
evt_3.description: Macduff reports that Malcolm and Donalbain have fled, which 'puts upon them / Suspicion of the deed,' thereby implicating the king's sons.

evt_4.title: Confirm coronation
evt_4.description: Macduff confirms the political outcome of the murder, stating that Macbeth 'is already named, and gone to Scone / To be invested' (crowned).

evt_5.title: Refuse invitation
evt_5.description: Ross asks Macduff if he will attend the coronation at Scone, and Macduff refuses, choosing instead to go to Fife, signaling his immediate political dissent.

evt_6.title: Bid farewell
evt_6.description: Ross bids a final farewell to the Old Man before departing.

fool-hero.justification: Lacks physical or political agency, but possesses significant intellectual capability and wisdom derived from long experience, allowing him to interpret the moral chaos.

angel-demon.justification: A pure voice of traditional morality and virtue, lamenting the unnatural evil and offering blessings to those who seek good.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Interprets the present entirely through the lens of past experience and established natural/moral order. Highly conservative and serious.

fool-hero.justification: A capable nobleman and effective observer. He understands the political implications and acts decisively by choosing to attend the coronation at Scone.

angel-demon.justification: Aligned with the virtuous order, lamenting the unnaturalness of the regicide. He is pragmatic, however, quickly accepting the new political reality (Macbeth's rise).

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Focused on interpreting chaos by referencing established natural laws ('Gainst nature still!') and adhering to political protocol (attending the coronation).

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable, intelligent, and politically astute. He immediately sees through the official narrative and makes a powerful, independent decision to resist the new regime.

angel-demon.justification: Acts as a moral anchor, expressing deep suspicion of the new power structure and refusing to participate in the coronation, marking him as a defender of legitimate virtue.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Deeply committed to the established moral and political order (Traditionalist), but his refusal to follow the immediate political tradition (attending Scone) is an unconventional act of resistance.

evt_1.title: Introspect
evt_1.description: Banquo reflects on the fulfillment of the witches' prophecy for Macbeth and suspects foul play, while also considering the hope the prophecy gives him regarding his own lineage.

evt_2.title: Invite
evt_2.description: Macbeth formally requests Banquo's presence at the 'solemn supper' that night.

evt_3.title: Pledge allegiance
evt_3.description: Banquo responds by pledging his duties and obedience to Macbeth's command with an 'indissoluble tie'.

evt_4.title: Interrogate
evt_4.description: Macbeth questions Banquo extensively about his riding plans for the afternoon (distance, time, and if Fleance accompanies him), gathering crucial information for the planned assassination.

evt_5.title: Dismiss court
evt_5.description: After Banquo exits, Macbeth dismisses the entire court, stating he wishes to be alone until supper time.

evt_6.title: Summon
evt_6.description: Macbeth asks the attendant if the waiting men (the murderers) are present and orders him to bring them forward.

evt_7.title: Resolve murder
evt_7.description: In a soliloquy, Macbeth expresses his deep fear of Banquo and his lineage, resolving that he must eliminate Banquo to secure his own crown ('To be thus is nothing, But to be safely thus').

evt_8.title: Initiate plot discussion
evt_8.description: Macbeth begins the conversation with the murderers by confirming their previous meeting and asking if they have considered his speeches.

evt_9.title: Manipulate
evt_9.description: Macbeth manipulates the murderers by convincing them that Banquo was the true source of their past misfortunes and challenging their manhood and patience.

evt_10.title: Express desperation
evt_10.description: Both murderers express their extreme desperation and willingness to risk their lives or commit violence due to their miserable circumstances.

evt_11.title: Justify secrecy
evt_11.description: Macbeth explains that he cannot openly kill Banquo due to mutual friends, justifying why he needs their assistance and must mask the business.

evt_12.title: Accept commission
evt_12.description: The murderers confirm their resolution and agree to perform whatever Macbeth commands.

evt_13.title: Issue instructions
evt_13.description: Macbeth gives detailed logistical instructions, specifying the timing ('to-night'), the location ('from the palace'), and crucially, expanding the target list to include Fleance, Banquo's son.

evt_14.title: Confirm plot conclusion
evt_14.description: After the murderers exit, Macbeth confirms the plot is finalized and Banquo's fate is sealed for that night.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable, both as a warrior (implied) and intellectually. Macbeth fears his 'royalty of nature' and the 'wisdom that doth guide his valour to act in safety,' indicating high innate potency and competence.

angel-demon.justification: The moral anchor of the scene. He is dutiful, loyal to the crown (Macbeth, despite suspicion), and maintains a virtuous orientation, resisting the temptation of the prophecy.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Strictly adheres to courtly protocol and duty ('Command upon me, to the which my duties / Are with a most indissoluble tie'). His behavior is serious and predictable.

fool-hero.justification: Possesses immense political power (King) and high intelligence, demonstrated by his complex manipulation of the Murderers. However, his deep paranoia ('To be thus is nothing, But to be safely thus') indicates internal weakness and instability.

angel-demon.justification: Fully corrupted. He has murdered Duncan, 'filed' his mind, and explicitly states he has given his 'eternal jewel' (soul) to the 'common enemy of man.' He is actively plotting the murder of his friend and a child.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Having already committed regicide (the ultimate rejection of tradition), he is now engaged in highly creative, unpredictable, and revolutionary plotting to defy fate and secure his position through further violence.

fool-hero.justification: Capable and purposeful in her role as Queen, ensuring the courtly facade is maintained and protocol is followed, demonstrating competence in social management.

angel-demon.justification: Complicit in the previous murder and actively supporting the corrupt regime. Her actions are dangerous and depraved, masked by a veneer of virtue.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Her focus in this scene is entirely on upholding the serious, predictable rituals of the court (the feast, the welcome) to stabilize their revolutionary position, making her behavior highly Traditionalist.

fool-hero.justification: A minor character, but competent and effective in following orders and relaying information accurately and promptly.

angel-demon.justification: Morally neutral; simply performing the duties of a servant for the current ruler, regardless of the ruler's virtue.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: The role is defined by adherence to strict protocol and predictable service within the established hierarchy.

fool-hero.justification: Possesses the physical capability and resolve to commit murder, but is intellectually weak, easily manipulated by Macbeth's false narrative about Banquo being the source of his misfortune.

angel-demon.justification: Driven by desperation and a desire for revenge/gain, willing to commit a heinous act (murder) for personal benefit, aligning himself with corruption.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His life is 'tugg'd with fortune,' leading him to a reckless state where he will 'set my lie on any chance' to mend it, indicating a radical, unpredictable rejection of his current circumstances.

fool-hero.justification: Incensed by the world's 'vile blows' and resolved to be 'reckless what I do to spite the world,' showing determination and physical capability, but lacking strategic intelligence.

angel-demon.justification: Driven by spite and desperation, willing to commit murder. Highly dangerous and corrupt.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His desire to 'spite the world' through reckless action is a highly unpredictable and anti-traditional stance.

evt_1.title: Inquire
evt_1.description: Lady Macbeth asks the Servant about Banquo's status and travel plans.

evt_2.title: Command attendance
evt_2.description: Lady Macbeth instructs the Servant to tell the King (Macbeth) that she wishes to speak with him.

evt_3.title: Introspect
evt_3.description: Lady Macbeth reflects privately on their current state of discontent and the danger of dwelling in 'doubtful joy' after the murder.

evt_4.title: Chide worry
evt_4.description: Lady Macbeth confronts Macbeth about his isolation and obsessive, sorrowful thoughts regarding the past deed, urging him to accept that 'what's done is done.'

evt_5.title: Express despair
evt_5.description: Macbeth expresses his profound mental anguish, stating they have only 'scotch'd the snake, not kill'd it,' and that he suffers from terrible dreams and fear.

evt_6.title: Urge composure
evt_6.description: Lady Macbeth instructs Macbeth to hide his 'rugged looks' and appear 'bright and jovial' for their guests.

evt_7.title: Demand hypocrisy
evt_7.description: Macbeth agrees to the deception and, in turn, demands Lady Macbeth also flatter Banquo and 'make our faces vizards to our hearts.'

evt_8.title: Dismiss worry
evt_8.description: Lady Macbeth attempts to stop Macbeth from dwelling on the necessity of their current deceitful behavior.

evt_9.title: Reveal anxiety source
evt_9.description: Macbeth reveals the specific cause of his mental torment: the fact that 'Banquo, and his Fleance, lives.'

evt_10.title: Offer reassurance
evt_10.description: Lady Macbeth reminds Macbeth that Banquo and Fleance are mortal ('nature's copy's not eterne').

evt_11.title: Hint at murder
evt_11.description: Macbeth takes comfort in their mortality and hints strongly that a 'deed of dreadful note' will be done before night ends.

evt_12.title: Exclude from plot
evt_12.description: When Lady Macbeth asks what is to be done, Macbeth deliberately excludes her from the details of the plan, telling her to 'Be innocent of the knowledge' until the deed is done.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable and purposeful. She attempts to manage Macbeth's psychological state, offering strategic advice and dismissing guilt ('what's done is done'). She quickly accepts the necessity of further violence.

angel-demon.justification: Deeply corrupt, having instigated regicide. She advocates for continued deception and moral compromise to secure power, stating it is 'safer to be that which we destroy' than live in fear.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: She rejects traditional morality and order. Her focus is on creative deception ('make our faces vizards to our hearts') and radical, unpredictable actions necessary to maintain the usurped throne.

fool-hero.justification: Competent in his role, accurately relaying information and following instructions, but possesses no significant innate power or influence.

angel-demon.justification: Neutral. He is merely an agent of the court, performing duties without moral judgment or personal agenda.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Strictly adheres to the established protocol and hierarchy of court service. Highly predictable behavior.

fool-hero.justification: Retains high external power (King, capable of ordering murder), but his internal state is severely compromised by guilt, paranoia, and fear ('full of scorpions is my mind'), leading to mental incompetence and paralysis.

angel-demon.justification: Fully immersed in corruption. He is actively planning the unprovoked murder of Banquo and Fleance, calling upon 'black Hecate' and 'seeling night' to aid his bloody deeds.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Driven by the need for radical, violent solutions to stabilize his revolutionary position. His language is highly creative and evocative of chaos, embracing unpredictable, dark actions ('A deed of dreadful note').

evt_1.title: Verify orders
evt_1.description: The First Murderer questions the Third Murderer's presence and authority, which the Third Murderer confirms came from Macbeth.

evt_2.title: Justify presence
evt_2.description: The Second Murderer defends the Third Murderer, stating that since Macbeth delivered the instructions, there is no need for mistrust.

evt_3.title: Integrate team
evt_3.description: The First Murderer accepts the justification and commands the Third Murderer to 'stand with us,' finalizing the murder team.

evt_4.title: Signal arrival
evt_4.description: Banquo calls out for a light, signaling his immediate proximity and confirming the target's arrival to the waiting murderers.

evt_5.title: Initiate confrontation
evt_5.description: Banquo comments on the weather, and the First Murderer responds with the ominous 'Let it come down,' revealing their presence and initiating the attack.

evt_6.title: Murder
evt_6.description: The three murderers collectively set upon and kill Banquo.

evt_7.title: Command escape
evt_7.description: As he is dying, Banquo warns Fleance of the treachery and commands him to flee.

evt_8.title: Escape
evt_8.description: Fleance successfully flees the scene, evading the murderers and frustrating Macbeth's plan.

evt_9.title: Assess failure
evt_9.description: The Second Murderer assesses the outcome, concluding that since 'the son is fled,' they have 'lost / Best half of our affair.'

evt_10.title: Command retreat
evt_10.description: The First Murderer commands the group to leave the scene and report the partial success to Macbeth.

fool-hero.justification: Capable enough to lead the ambush and successfully kill Banquo, demonstrating purpose and power. However, the failure to secure Fleance shows a critical lapse in competence.

angel-demon.justification: A hired assassin committing treachery and murder against a loyal nobleman. Represents extreme corruption and danger.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Serious and focused on the professional execution of the task (Traditionalist), but the task itself is a radical, unpredictable act of political violence (Adventurer context).

fool-hero.justification: Competent in identifying the target and confirming the plan, but his line 'We have lost / Best half of our affair' emphasizes the failure to complete the mission fully.

angel-demon.justification: A hired assassin, fully complicit in the corrupt act of murder.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Highly focused on the expected outcome and procedure (Traditionalist). Expresses concern when the plan deviates.

fool-hero.justification: Demonstrates high competence in intelligence and logistics, confirming Macbeth's involvement and Banquo's routine. Acts as the most capable and detail-oriented of the group.

angel-demon.justification: The agent sent by Macbeth to ensure the murder, representing the highest level of calculated corruption.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His role is to ensure the plan is followed precisely and professionally, emphasizing adherence to procedure and seriousness.

fool-hero.justification: A capable nobleman and warrior, but is caught off guard and killed. His final, purposeful act of self-sacrifice ('Fly, good Fleance, fly') to ensure his son's survival is highly heroic.

angel-demon.justification: The virtuous victim of treachery. Represents loyalty, purity, and the established moral order being violently overthrown.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Grounded, serious, and focused on the mundane reality ('It will be rain to-night'). Represents the predictable, stable world Macbeth is destroying.

fool-hero.justification: Though young, his successful escape under extreme duress demonstrates quick action and capability, fulfilling the heroic mandate of survival.

angel-demon.justification: An innocent victim who escapes corruption, representing the hope for future virtue and justice.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His action is pure, unpredictable flight and chaos, disrupting the carefully laid plans of the murderers. This sudden, successful deviation is highly adventurous.

evt_1.title: Welcome guests
evt_1.description: Macbeth instructs the Lords to sit down and offers a hearty welcome, setting the scene for the feast.

evt_2.title: Acknowledge welcome
evt_2.description: The Lords collectively thank Macbeth for his welcome.

evt_3.title: Inquire about murder
evt_3.description: Macbeth notices the blood on the Murderer's face and asks directly, 'Is he dispatch'd?' (referring to Banquo).

evt_4.title: Report success and failure
evt_4.description: The Murderer confirms Banquo's death ('his throat is cut') but reports the critical failure: 'Fleance is 'scaped.'

evt_5.title: Experience fear
evt_5.description: Upon hearing Fleance escaped, Macbeth realizes his threat is not fully neutralized, stating, 'Then comes my fit again,' plunging him into 'saucy doubts and fears.'

evt_6.title: Dismiss agent
evt_6.description: Macbeth, satisfied with Banquo's death, tells the Murderer, 'Get thee gone: to-morrow / We'll hear, ourselves, again,' dismissing him from the hall.

evt_7.title: Occupy seat
evt_7.description: The Ghost of Banquo enters and sits in Macbeth's reserved place, a physical action that initiates Macbeth's public breakdown.

evt_8.title: Challenge apparition
evt_8.description: Macbeth, seeing the Ghost, addresses it directly, accusing it of being responsible for its appearance: 'Thou canst not say I did it: never shake / Thy gory locks at me.'

evt_9.title: Maintain order
evt_9.description: As the Lords begin to rise, Lady Macbeth commands them to stay seated, explaining Macbeth's fit as a common, momentary illness.

evt_10.title: Rebuke husband
evt_10.description: Lady Macbeth privately challenges Macbeth's courage, asking 'Are you a man?' and dismissing the Ghost as 'the very painting of your fear.'

evt_11.title: Banish apparition
evt_11.description: Macbeth commands the Ghost to leave ('Avaunt! and quit my sight!'), causing it to vanish for the second time.

evt_12.title: Terminate feast
evt_12.description: Realizing the situation is irreparable, Lady Macbeth abruptly ends the banquet, ordering the guests to leave immediately: 'Stand not upon the order of your going, / But go at once.'

evt_13.title: Question loyalty
evt_13.description: After the guests leave, Macbeth asks Lady Macbeth about Macduff's refusal to attend the feast: 'How say'st thou, that Macduff denies his person / At our great bidding?'

evt_14.title: Resolve to consult Witches
evt_14.description: Macbeth decides to seek out the Weird Sisters immediately to learn the worst of his fate: 'I will to-morrow, / And betimes I will, to the weird sisters.'

evt_15.title: Commit to evil
evt_15.description: Macbeth acknowledges he is too deep in murder to turn back, resolving to act on his dark thoughts without hesitation: 'I am in blood / Stepp'd in so far that, should I wade no more, / Returning were as tedious as go o'er.'

fool-hero.justification: High innate potency (King, capable of complex action), but his mental state is weak and incompetent. His fear and breakdown destroy the political stability he sought, making him a Fool in the context of governance, though still a Hero in terms of raw power.

angel-demon.justification: Fully immersed in corruption and murder. He is dangerous, depraved, and committed to 'the worst means, the worst' for his own good.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His actions (regicide, seeing ghosts, planning further violence) are highly unpredictable and revolutionary, shattering all social and behavioral norms. He is driven by chaotic ambition.

fool-hero.justification: Extremely capable and purposeful. She maintains control, manages the crisis, and psychologically manipulates Macbeth, demonstrating high competence under pressure.

angel-demon.justification: The primary agent of corruption and arrogance in the scene, actively covering up murder and shaming her husband for his moral weakness.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: While attempting to enforce the traditional ceremony of the feast, her methods (lying, quick thinking, psychological attacks) are highly creative and unconventional, making her an Adventurer in crisis management.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable and effective in his primary task (killing Banquo), but the failure to secure Fleance represents a significant lapse in competence.

angel-demon.justification: A professional agent of depravity and violence, covered in the blood of his victim.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Operates strictly according to orders and professional standards. His role is serious, predictable, and lacks creative deviation.

fool-hero.justification: Possesses immense, terrifying power over Macbeth, capable of paralyzing the King and disrupting the entire court. A potent force of consequence.

angel-demon.justification: While terrifying (Demon), the Ghost functions as a force of moral reckoning and justice (Angel), punishing the corrupt King by manifesting his guilt.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: A highly unpredictable, supernatural intrusion that breaks the fundamental rules of life and death, shattering the established order of the feast.

fool-hero.justification: High status (Hero), but utterly passive and incompetent in understanding or controlling the crisis. They are easily dismissed and manipulated by Lady Macbeth.

angel-demon.justification: Represent the loyal, virtuous social order that Macbeth has betrayed. They are polite and concerned for their King.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Strictly adhere to court protocol and ceremony, focused entirely on maintaining the established order of the feast.

fool-hero.justification: Competent in his role as a noble and guest, but completely lacks the insight or power to grasp the true nature of Macbeth's distress.

angel-demon.justification: A loyal subject focused on politeness and the King's well-being.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Focused entirely on protocol and order, attempting to seat the King correctly.

fool-hero.justification: Slightly more capable than the general Lords, attempting social diplomacy (explaining Banquo's absence) and showing initiative in trying to manage the crisis when Macbeth breaks down.

angel-demon.justification: A loyal subject focused on politeness and maintaining the social facade.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Focused on maintaining the social structure and ceremony, adhering strictly to courtly behavior.

evt_1.title: Inquire state
evt_1.description: The First Witch observes Hecate's angry demeanor and asks why she is upset.

evt_2.title: Chastise subordinates
evt_2.description: Hecate scolds the Witches ('beldams') for being 'Saucy and overbold' and for dealing with Macbeth without consulting her, the mistress of their charms.

evt_3.title: Order preparation
evt_3.description: Hecate commands the Witches to make amends by meeting her at the pit of Acheron in the morning, bringing their vessels and spells, where Macbeth will come to learn his destiny.

evt_4.title: Plan destruction
evt_4.description: Hecate outlines her personal plan to catch a 'vaporous drop profound' from the moon and distill it to raise artificial sprites that will lead Macbeth to his 'confusion,' causing him to spurn fate and scorn death.

evt_5.title: Coordinate departure
evt_5.description: The First Witch urges the other Witches to hurry and leave, complying with Hecate's order to prepare for the next meeting.

fool-hero.justification: As the 'mistress of your charms' and 'close contriver of all harms,' Hecate demonstrates supreme authority, strategic intelligence, and magical capability (planning to catch the 'vaporous drop profound' and raise artificial sprites). She is highly purposeful.

angel-demon.justification: She is the embodiment of dark, corrupting power, focused entirely on leading Macbeth to 'confusion' by exploiting his fatal flaw ('security'). Her orientation is purely malicious and depraved.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: While she demands adherence to hierarchy (Traditionalist aspect, being angry at the Witches for acting without her), her methods (complex, high-level magic) and her goal (creating chaos and false security to destroy a king) are highly creative and disruptive (Adventurer).

fool-hero.justification: The Witches possess significant magical power ('trade and traffic with Macbeth'), but they are clearly subordinate to Hecate and are chastised for their lack of judgment ('saucy and overbold'), indicating a relative lack of strategic intelligence compared to their mistress.

angel-demon.justification: They are agents of 'affairs of death' and corruption, actively working to manipulate and harm mortals. Their moral orientation is fundamentally demonic.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: The Witches are inherently chaotic, unpredictable, and creative in their use of riddles and spells. Although they are obedient to Hecate in this scene, their core nature and the actions Hecate scolds them for are highly Adventurous.

evt_1.title: Condemn tyranny
evt_1.description: Lennox speaks ironically to the Lord, reviewing the suspicious deaths of Duncan and Banquo and Macbeth's subsequent actions (killing the guards), thereby establishing their shared understanding of Macbeth's tyrannical and murderous reign.

evt_2.title: Inquire location
evt_2.description: Lennox asks the Lord for intelligence regarding the whereabouts of Macduff, who is currently in disgrace.

evt_3.title: Report alliance
evt_3.description: The Lord reports that Malcolm is in England and that Macduff has gone there to seek military aid from King Edward, Northumberland, and Siward to overthrow Macbeth.

evt_4.title: Refuse summons
evt_4.description: The Lord confirms that Macbeth sent a messenger to Macduff, and Macduff openly defied the tyrant by giving an 'absolute 'Sir, not I'' as an answer.

evt_5.title: Mobilize military
evt_5.description: The Lord reports that the news of Macduff's actions has 'exasperate the king' (Macbeth) and that he 'Prepares for some attempt of war' against the growing opposition.

evt_6.title: Pray for aid
evt_6.description: Lennox and the Lord collectively express hope and prayer for a 'holy angel' to assist Macduff and bring a 'swift blessing' (military success) back to Scotland.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable and intelligent, using sophisticated irony and coded language to discuss treason and tyranny without explicitly incriminating himself, demonstrating political shrewdness.

angel-demon.justification: Morally aligned against the 'hand accursed' (Macbeth) and seeking the restoration of virtue and order (Angel).

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Serious and cautious in his approach, focused on restoring the traditional, legitimate monarchy, though his current actions involve covert political risk.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable in gathering intelligence, assessing the political landscape, and articulating the complex plan for resistance involving foreign aid.

angel-demon.justification: Explicitly focused on restoring peace, safety, and 'free honours,' acting as a virtuous agent against the tyrant.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Focused entirely on restoring the 'due of birth' (Malcolm) and traditional feudal homage, reinforcing established order.

fool-hero.justification: Currently holds absolute power and maintains control through decisive, albeit violent, action. Highly potent and capable as a ruler/tyrant.

angel-demon.justification: Described as the 'tyrant' ruling under a 'hand accursed,' responsible for 'damned fact[s]' and 'bloody knives.' The embodiment of corruption.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Violently overthrew the traditional order. His rule is chaotic, unpredictable, and marked by revolutionary violence and paranoia.

fool-hero.justification: A capable king, but his vulnerability and death demonstrate a lack of necessary political potency to survive the threat.

angel-demon.justification: Referred to as 'gracious Duncan' and 'gracious father.' The ultimate symbol of virtuous, pious rule.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: The embodiment of legitimate, established, and serious royal tradition.

fool-hero.justification: Described as 'right-valiant,' indicating high innate capability and military prowess.

angel-demon.justification: A loyal subject and moral man, unjustly murdered by the tyrant.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: A loyal soldier adhering strictly to the established social and military order.

fool-hero.justification: Demonstrates high capability and wisdom by refusing the tyrant's summons and strategically seeking powerful foreign aid.

angel-demon.justification: Seeking aid from the 'holy king' to restore justice and virtue to Scotland.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: While his ultimate goal is Traditional (restoring Malcolm), his current actions involve revolutionary defiance, flight, and initiating a foreign invasion, making his behavior highly Adventurous.

fool-hero.justification: The focus of the rebellion, capable of securing powerful allies and preparing for war.

angel-demon.justification: The rightful, virtuous heir, seeking to reclaim the 'due of birth' and end the tyranny.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Represents the legitimate, traditional line of succession and the restoration of order.

fool-hero.justification: A powerful monarch whose influence and military aid are crucial to the Scottish cause.

angel-demon.justification: Referred to as 'the most pious Edward' and 'the holy king,' representing external moral purity and grace.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: A stable, established monarch, representing order and tradition.

fool-hero.justification: Competent enough to deliver the summons and understand the political implications, but his actions are driven by fear and malice.

angel-demon.justification: An agent of the tyrant, conveying threats and malice ('You'll rue the time'). Aligned with the corrupt regime.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: While performing a traditional role (messenger), his behavior is highly unprofessional, unpredictable, and personally defiant/threatening ('turns me his back, And hums').

evt_1.title: Brew charm
evt_1.description: The three witches collectively perform the ritual, adding ingredients to the cauldron and chanting the refrain ('Double, double toil and trouble'), creating the powerful, plot-driving charm.

evt_2.title: Direct ritual
evt_2.description: Hecate enters, commends the witches' efforts, and instructs them to continue the enchantment with music and song.

evt_3.title: Conjure answers
evt_3.description: Macbeth confronts the witches and uses powerful, threatening language to conjure them to answer his questions, regardless of the cosmic cost.

evt_4.title: Offer choice
evt_4.description: The First Witch offers Macbeth the choice of hearing the prophecies from the witches themselves or from their 'masters' (the apparitions).

evt_5.title: Summon apparition
evt_5.description: The witches collectively add the final ingredients and chant the spell necessary to summon the first apparition (the Armed Head).

evt_6.title: Warn
evt_6.description: The First Apparition delivers the warning to Macbeth to 'beware Macduff, / Beware the thane of Fife.'

evt_7.title: Assure invulnerability
evt_7.description: The Second Apparition (Bloody Child) assures Macbeth that 'none of woman born / Shall harm Macbeth,' leading to a false sense of security.

evt_8.title: Resolve murder
evt_8.description: Macbeth internally resolves to kill Macduff despite the prophecy, stating he will 'make assurance double sure' and 'take a bond of fate.'

evt_9.title: Prophesy safety
evt_9.description: The Third Apparition (Crowned Child) delivers the prophecy that Macbeth will not be vanquished until Birnam Wood moves to Dunsinane Hill.

evt_10.title: Demand lineage
evt_10.description: Macbeth, despite the witches' refusal, insists and curses them, demanding to know if Banquo's issue will ever reign.

evt_11.title: Reveal future
evt_11.description: The witches collectively summon the final vision (the show of Eight Kings followed by Banquo's Ghost) to reveal the future lineage, horrifying Macbeth.

evt_12.title: Vanish
evt_12.description: After dancing, the witches and Hecate vanish, leaving Macbeth alone and enraged.

evt_13.title: Report flight
evt_13.description: Lennox enters and delivers the crucial news that Macduff has fled to England.

evt_14.title: Plan massacre
evt_14.description: Reacting instantly to Macduff's flight, Macbeth resolves to seize Macduff's castle and murder his entire family and household to ensure his purpose is not 'o'ertook.'

evt_15.title: Command escort
evt_15.description: Macbeth commands Lennox to bring him to the messengers who delivered the news, preparing to execute his new plan immediately.

fool-hero.justification: Possesses immense supernatural power, capable of controlling elements, summoning spirits, and creating potent, fate-altering charms.

angel-demon.justification: Engaged in explicit acts of malice, using vile ingredients (poisoned entrails, murderer's grease) to create a 'hell-broth' designed for 'powerful trouble'.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Highly unconventional and chaotic, using creative, rhyming spells and bizarre ingredients to disrupt natural and social order.

fool-hero.justification: Shares the collective supernatural power and capability of the Weird Sisters, contributing complex ingredients to the charm.

angel-demon.justification: Actively participates in the creation of the corrupting charm, noting the arrival of Macbeth as 'Something wicked this way comes'.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Part of the chaotic, creative ritual, using unconventional language and methods.

fool-hero.justification: Shares the collective supernatural power and capability, contributing the most gruesome ingredients (e.g., 'Finger of birth-strangled babe').

angel-demon.justification: Deeply corrupt, focused on creating a 'gruel thick and slab' using ingredients derived from murder and blasphemy.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Part of the chaotic, creative ritual, focused on disruption and the unconventional.

fool-hero.justification: The superior power, commanding the Witches and overseeing the entire ritual, demonstrating ultimate control over the dark arts in this context.

angel-demon.justification: The mistress of the dark arts, explicitly commending the Witches for their malicious work and organizing further enchantment.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: While she imposes structure (a song and dance), the purpose is to enhance the chaotic, unconventional magic ('Enchanting all that you put in').

fool-hero.justification: Retains the power of a king (Hero), but his intelligence and judgment are severely compromised by paranoia and desperation, leading him to blindly trust the Witches (Fool).

angel-demon.justification: Fully corrupted. He demands the Witches unleash cosmic destruction if necessary to satisfy his curiosity, and immediately resolves to commit mass murder (Macduff's family) based on the prophecies.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Driven by chaotic impulse, abandoning rational planning for immediate, unpredictable, and violent action ('The very firstlings of my heart shall be / The firstlings of my hand').

fool-hero.justification: A powerful, prophetic spirit capable of delivering crucial, though misleading, information.

angel-demon.justification: An instrument of the Witches, part of the demonic deception designed to manipulate Macbeth, despite the seemingly helpful warning.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Delivers a serious, direct, and specific warning, adhering to the structure of the prophecy ritual.

fool-hero.justification: A powerful, prophetic spirit delivering a key, seemingly impossible, condition.

angel-demon.justification: Encourages arrogance and bloodshed ('Be bloody, bold, and resolute'), deepening Macbeth's moral corruption.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: The prophecy itself is fantastical ('none of woman born'), but the delivery is serious and intended to solidify Macbeth's current, revolutionary path.

fool-hero.justification: A powerful, prophetic spirit delivering the final, most reassuring and deceptive condition.

angel-demon.justification: The ultimate tool of deception, providing false security that leads directly to Macbeth's downfall and further tyranny.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Delivers a serious, absolute statement based on an impossible, fantastical condition (the moving forest).
