fool-hero.justification: A competent messenger and loyal Thane, but lacks the high agency or power to influence the central conflict of the scene.

angel-demon.justification: Represents loyalty and the virtuous social order, delivering factual news without malice or deception.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Strictly adheres to protocol, delivering news (Macduff's flight) in a predictable, serious manner.

evt_1.title: Accuse husband
evt_1.description: Lady Macduff accuses her absent husband, Macduff, of madness and lack of love for fleeing the land and abandoning his family, expressing her feelings to Ross.

evt_2.title: Defend husband
evt_2.description: Ross attempts to defend Macduff's actions, suggesting his flight might be wisdom rather than fear, and urges Lady Macduff to 'school yourself'.

evt_3.title: Depart
evt_3.description: Ross takes his leave abruptly, citing the danger of the times and the potential disgrace of staying longer.

evt_4.title: Test loyalty
evt_4.description: Lady Macduff engages her Son in a dark, witty dialogue, testing his understanding of his father's supposed death and treason.

evt_5.title: Assert loyalty
evt_5.description: The Son demonstrates sharp wit and loyalty, refusing to believe his father is dead or a traitor, and cleverly turns his mother's questions back on her.

evt_6.title: Deliver warning
evt_6.description: A Messenger enters, warns Lady Macduff that danger is approaching, and advises her to flee with her children immediately.

evt_7.title: Flee
evt_7.description: The Messenger, having delivered the warning, immediately exits, stating he dares abide no longer due to the danger.

evt_8.title: Introspect
evt_8.description: Lady Macduff reflects on the moral paradox of the world, where innocence is dangerous, questioning why she should rely on the defense that she has 'done no harm'.

evt_9.title: Demand location
evt_9.description: The Murderers enter, and the First Murderer immediately confronts Lady Macduff, demanding to know the location of her husband.

evt_10.title: Challenge accusation
evt_10.description: The Son bravely defends his father's honor by calling the First Murderer a liar and a villain for labeling Macduff a traitor.

evt_11.title: Murder
evt_11.description: The First Murderer, enraged by the Son's defiance, stabs and kills him.

evt_12.title: Urge escape
evt_12.description: As he dies, the Son uses his last breath to urge his mother to run away.

evt_13.title: Engage in pursuit
evt_13.description: Lady Macduff flees the scene crying 'Murder!' while the Murderers immediately follow her to complete their assassination mission.

fool-hero.justification: High intellectual capability, sharp wit, and moral clarity (Hero), but physically vulnerable and ultimately unable to protect herself or her son (Fool) in the face of violence.

angel-demon.justification: Virtuous, focused on familial duty, and morally outraged by the perceived betrayal and the corruption of the times. A victim of evil.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Primarily focused on upholding traditional roles, loyalty, and duty (Traditionalist). Her dialogue with her son shows flashes of wit, but her overall mood is serious and focused on established order.

fool-hero.justification: Capable of navigating the treacherous political landscape, offering judicious advice, and managing his own safety. He is wise and competent, though constrained.

angel-demon.justification: Sympathetic, loyal to Macduff's honor, and morally opposed to the 'cruel times.' He is virtuous but cautious.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Adheres strictly to the protocols of a nobleman, offering formal comfort and defending the honor of a peer. Highly cautious and predictable in his actions.

fool-hero.justification: Physically weak (Fool), but demonstrates remarkable intellectual capability, sharp wit, and complex logical reasoning (Hero) far beyond his age.

angel-demon.justification: Utterly innocent, pure, and loyal to his father, culminating in his brave defense against the murderer.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His dialogue is highly playful, creative, and unpredictable, using humor and logic to challenge serious concepts (traitors, death, marriage).

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable and purposeful in assessing danger and delivering an urgent, life-saving warning, acting decisively before fleeing.

angel-demon.justification: Acts purely out of protective, selfless virtue, risking his own safety to warn the family.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: The *motive* is serious, but the *action* of breaking protocol and rushing in to deliver a warning is a radical, unpredictable intervention (Adventurer) against the established order of tyranny.

fool-hero.justification: Extremely capable and potent in violence, successfully executing the assigned task of assassination.

angel-demon.justification: An agent of corruption, violence, and depravity, murdering innocent women and children without remorse.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: The method is serious, direct, and predictable (following orders to kill). However, their role is to enforce the chaotic, revolutionary tyranny of Macbeth, which is inherently disruptive (Adventurer element).

evt_1.title: Propose retreat
evt_1.description: Malcolm suggests they seek a desolate shade to weep over Scotland's fate.

evt_2.title: Counter-propose action
evt_2.description: Macduff rejects weeping and urges Malcolm to take up the sword and fight for their 'down-fall'n birthdom'.

evt_3.title: Test loyalty
evt_3.description: Malcolm begins testing Macduff by expressing suspicion that Macduff might be trying to win favor with Macbeth by betraying Malcolm.

evt_4.title: Question commitment
evt_4.description: Malcolm presses Macduff on why he left his wife and children ('those strong knots of love') unprotected in Scotland.

evt_5.title: Lament fate
evt_5.description: Macduff, despairing over Malcolm's suspicions and the state of Scotland, cries out, 'Bleed, bleed, poor country!' and prepares to abandon Malcolm, believing him unworthy.

evt_6.title: Reveal true plan
evt_6.description: Malcolm stops the test, apologizes for his suspicion, and reveals that he has already secured military aid from England (Siward and thousands of men).

evt_7.title: Slander self (Test 2)
evt_7.description: Malcolm continues his test by listing exaggerated vices (boundless lust and avarice) to see if Macduff would tolerate a corrupt king for the sake of removing Macbeth.

evt_8.title: Condemn successor
evt_8.description: Macduff, believing Malcolm's self-slanders, declares him unfit to govern and prepares to leave, confirming his integrity.

evt_9.title: Commit to alliance
evt_9.description: Malcolm retracts his slanders, praises Macduff's 'noble passion' (integrity), and commits himself and the English forces to Macduff's direction.

evt_10.title: Inquire about King Edward
evt_10.description: Malcolm asks the Doctor if King Edward is coming forth.

evt_11.title: Report healing power
evt_11.description: The Doctor reports that King Edward is curing the sick (the 'evil') through his touch, establishing Edward's divine grace.

evt_12.title: Request national update
evt_12.description: Macduff greets Ross and asks for an update on the state of Scotland.

evt_13.title: Report national misery
evt_13.description: Ross describes Scotland as a 'grave' where sorrow and violence are constant, and good men die quickly.

evt_14.title: Inquire about family
evt_14.description: Macduff asks Ross specifically about the welfare of his wife and children.

evt_15.title: Deliver tragic news
evt_15.description: Ross reveals that Macduff's castle was surprised and his wife and children were 'savagely slaughter'd'.

evt_16.title: Advise emotional control
evt_16.description: Malcolm urges Macduff to give sorrow words and convert his grief into anger and revenge.

evt_17.title: Vow vengeance
evt_17.description: Macduff processes his grief, blames himself for the deaths, and resolves to meet Macbeth 'front to front' in battle.

evt_18.title: Initiate invasion
evt_18.description: Malcolm confirms their power is ready and urges Macduff to depart immediately to join the forces and begin the invasion.

fool-hero.justification: Demonstrates high intellectual capability and strategic purpose by executing a complex psychological test on Macduff to ensure his loyalty and integrity, proving himself a capable future leader with military resources (Siward and 10,000 men).

angel-demon.justification: Though he pretends to embody every vice (Demon) during the test, his true nature is revealed as pure, honest, and possessing all 'king-becoming graces' (Angel).

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His ultimate goal is the restoration of traditional order (Traditionalist), but his method of achieving trust through elaborate deception and testing is highly unconventional and creative (Adventurer).

fool-hero.justification: Highly purposeful and capable, immediately advocating for military action ('Hold fast the mortal sword') rather than passive grief. His grief is quickly channeled into focused, heroic vengeance.

angel-demon.justification: Exhibits profound moral integrity, rejecting Malcolm's supposed vices and prioritizing the welfare of Scotland above all else. His anger is righteous and directed solely at the tyrant.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Driven by traditional concepts of duty, honor, and loyalty to the rightful heir. His response to tyranny is the predictable, serious call to arms.

fool-hero.justification: Competent in his role as a messenger, capable of travel, observation, and reporting the dire state of Scotland and the military situation, though he lacks active martial potency.

angel-demon.justification: Loyal to Macduff and the cause of Scotland. He is honest, though reluctant, in delivering the tragic news, aligning him with the virtuous side.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Adheres to the traditional role of a noble messenger, delivering news and urging action based on established political necessity, but his emotional language adds a degree of dramatic flair.

fool-hero.justification: A knowledgeable professional (physician) who confirms the miraculous healing power of King Edward, demonstrating competence in his field, though his power is secondary to the King's divine gift.

angel-demon.justification: Represents healing, sanctity, and the virtuous order of the English court, confirming the divine grace bestowed upon the King.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Strictly adheres to established medical and court protocol, confirming the traditional, divinely sanctioned power of the monarchy.

fool-hero.justification: Currently holds absolute power and is capable of massive, destructive action (slaughtering Macduff's family, maintaining tyranny). Highly potent in immediate capability.

angel-demon.justification: Referred to as 'tyrant,' 'devilish,' and 'fiend of Scotland.' He embodies corruption, malice, and depravity, acting as the ultimate antagonist.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Rules through unpredictable, chaotic, and creative cruelty (e.g., the calculated slaughter of innocents), having violently overthrown the traditional order.

fool-hero.justification: Possesses divine healing power ('miraculous work') and commands significant military resources (Siward and 10,000 men), demonstrating high potency and capability.

angel-demon.justification: Embodies sanctity, grace, mercy, and virtue, acting as the moral and spiritual counterpoint to Macbeth.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Represents the ideal, divinely sanctioned, stable, and predictable monarch, focused entirely on maintaining order and justice.

evt_1.title: Question report
evt_1.description: The Doctor questions the Gentlewoman's previous report of Lady Macbeth's sleepwalking, stating he has seen 'no truth in your report' after two nights of watching.

evt_2.title: Perform ritual
evt_2.description: The Gentlewoman reports Lady Macbeth's habitual sleepwalking actions: rising, dressing, unlocking her closet, taking paper, writing, sealing it, and returning to bed, all while asleep.

evt_3.title: Request testimony
evt_3.description: The Doctor presses the Gentlewoman to reveal what she has heard Lady Macbeth say during her sleepwalking episodes.

evt_4.title: Refuse testimony
evt_4.description: The Gentlewoman refuses to report Lady Macbeth's words to the Doctor or anyone else, citing the lack of a witness to confirm her speech.

evt_5.title: Enter scene
evt_5.description: Lady Macbeth enters the scene, carrying a taper, initiating the central event of the scene.

evt_6.title: Manifest guilt
evt_6.description: Lady Macbeth begins the accustomed action of rubbing her hands, attempting to wash away imaginary blood, a physical manifestation of her guilt.

evt_7.title: Confess guilt (aloud)
evt_7.description: Lady Macbeth speaks aloud in her sleep, revealing her guilt over Duncan's murder ('Out, damned spot!') and referencing Macbeth's cowardice and the murder of the Thane of Fife's wife. This information is overheard by the observers.

evt_8.title: Resolve to record
evt_8.description: Upon hearing Lady Macbeth speak, the Doctor resolves to write down her words to strengthen his memory and document the confession.

evt_9.title: Express despair
evt_9.description: Lady Macbeth laments the indelible nature of the blood ('Here's the smell of the blood still') and sighs deeply, indicating the severe charge upon her heart.

evt_10.title: Declare incapacity
evt_10.description: The Doctor declares that Lady Macbeth's condition is 'beyond my practise,' recognizing it as a spiritual or mental illness rather than a physical one.

evt_11.title: Relive past event
evt_11.description: Lady Macbeth, still sleepwalking, relives the night of the murder, issuing commands to an imaginary Macbeth ('Wash your hands,' 'Banquo's buried'), and concluding that 'What's done cannot be undone.'

evt_12.title: Issue safety instructions
evt_12.description: The Doctor, recognizing the danger of her mental state, instructs the Gentlewoman to 'Look after her,' 'Remove from her the means of all annoyance,' and 'still keep eyes upon her.'

evt_13.title: Realize danger
evt_13.description: The Doctor reflects internally on the political implications of what he has witnessed, stating his mind is 'mated, and amazed' and that he 'think[s], but dare not speak.'

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable and intelligent in his professional field (diagnosis, observation, methodical note-taking). However, he recognizes the limits of his medical power against a spiritual/moral ailment, admitting the disease is 'beyond my practise'.

angel-demon.justification: Acts purely as a benevolent healer and moral observer. He seeks truth and expresses concern for Lady Macbeth's soul, concluding she needs 'the divine'.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Represents established science and professional protocol. He is shocked by the 'great perturbation in nature' and the 'unnatural deeds' which fall outside his predictable, serious framework.

fool-hero.justification: Competent and observant in her role, providing detailed, accurate reports of Lady Macbeth's actions. She demonstrates intellectual capability by understanding the gravity of the situation and refusing to report treasonous speech without a witness.

angel-demon.justification: Morally upright and cautious. She is loyal to her mistress but refuses to compromise her own virtue by spreading dangerous, unconfirmed secrets. She expresses horror at the corruption she witnesses.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Adheres strictly to social and legal norms (requiring a witness). She is focused on duty and order, and is deeply disturbed by the unpredictable, unnatural behavior of the Queen.

fool-hero.justification: Her former heroic potency (willpower, control) has completely collapsed. She is mentally incompetent, unable to control her own actions or thoughts, consumed by guilt, and physically weak (rubbing her hands in a futile attempt to wash away the 'spot').

angel-demon.justification: The scene is a direct manifestation of her extreme moral corruption. She confesses to regicide ('tis time to do't'), the murder of Banquo, and the blood of Duncan, confirming her status as a deeply depraved figure.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Her actions are the ultimate disruption of order and tradition (regicide, tyranny). Her sleepwalking is a highly unpredictable, chaotic, and creative manifestation of psychological breakdown, reliving revolutionary acts.

evt_1.title: Report enemy status
evt_1.description: Menteith informs the other Thanes that the English forces, led by Malcolm, Siward, and Macduff, are approaching and are motivated by deep revenge.

evt_2.title: Confirm rendezvous point
evt_2.description: Angus confirms the strategic location where they will meet the English army: near Birnam wood.

evt_3.title: Provide intelligence
evt_3.description: Lennox provides specific information about the invading forces, confirming Donalbain's absence but noting the presence of Siward's son and many young, inexperienced soldiers.

evt_4.title: Assess enemy defense
evt_4.description: Caithness assesses Macbeth's current state, noting he is strongly fortifying Dunsinane but is mentally unstable ('mad' or in 'valiant fury') and unable to maintain control.

evt_5.title: Detail psychological collapse
evt_5.description: Angus elaborates on Macbeth's failure, stating that his murders haunt him, his title is loose, and his soldiers obey only out of command, not love.

evt_6.title: Commit to cause and march
evt_6.description: Caithness proposes they march to give obedience to Malcolm (the 'medicine of the sickly weal') and sacrifice themselves for Scotland. Lennox agrees, and the Thanes collectively execute the plan by marching toward Birnam.

fool-hero.justification: A capable Thane and military leader actively participating in the rebellion. Provides crucial intelligence regarding the approaching forces.

angel-demon.justification: Aligned with the virtuous cause of restoring Malcolm and condemning Macbeth's tyranny and psychological breakdown.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Serious and purposeful in his duty to restore the traditional monarchy, though the act of rebellion itself carries some Adventurer risk.

fool-hero.justification: Highly capable and intelligent, delivering the most insightful and powerful diagnosis of Macbeth's failure (the 'dwarfish thief' metaphor).

angel-demon.justification: Acts as a strong moral voice, focusing explicitly on Macbeth's 'secret murders' and 'faith-breach.' Dedicated to justice.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Focused on upholding established moral and political norms, using serious language to condemn the disruption of order.

fool-hero.justification: A competent leader who provides intelligence on Macbeth's fortifications and drives the group toward action.

angel-demon.justification: Seeks the 'medicine of the sickly weal' (Malcolm), indicating a strong moral orientation toward healing the corrupted state.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Highly focused on duty and 'obedience where 'tis truly owed,' emphasizing the restoration of legitimate hierarchy.

fool-hero.justification: Demonstrates specific knowledge (the file of gentry) and high intellectual capability through his poetic summary of their mission ('drown the weeds').

angel-demon.justification: His final lines frame the mission as a moral purge, dedicated to nurturing the 'sovereign flower' (virtue/legitimacy) and destroying the 'weeds' (corruption/Macbeth).

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Serious and focused on restoring the natural and traditional order of the kingdom, using metaphors of growth and hierarchy.

evt_1.title: Reaffirm confidence
evt_1.description: Macbeth dismisses the reports of fleeing thanes and reaffirms his absolute confidence, relying entirely on the prophecies that he cannot be defeated until Birnam Wood moves or by a man born of woman.

evt_2.title: Berate
evt_2.description: Macbeth severely insults the terrified Servant, calling him a 'cream-faced loon' and 'lily-liver'd boy' for his fearful appearance.

evt_3.title: Report threat
evt_3.description: The Servant, under duress, reports the presence of ten thousand English soldiers.

evt_4.title: Dismiss
evt_4.description: Macbeth orders the Servant to leave immediately ('Take thy face hence').

evt_5.title: Lament fate
evt_5.description: Macbeth reflects introspectively on his life, acknowledging that he has lost the traditional comforts of old age (honor, love, friends) and is left only with curses and false respect.

evt_6.title: Confirm intelligence
evt_6.description: Seyton confirms that all the bad news previously reported (presumably the approach of the English army and the flight of the thanes) is true.

evt_7.title: Issue military orders
evt_7.description: Macbeth demands his armor and issues urgent, broad commands to Seyton to send out more horses and execute anyone who speaks of fear, demonstrating his desperate attempt to control the situation.

evt_8.title: Inquire about health
evt_8.description: Macbeth shifts his focus from the battle preparations to ask the Doctor about Lady Macbeth's condition.

evt_9.title: Diagnose illness
evt_9.description: The Doctor diagnoses Lady Macbeth as suffering from 'thick coming fancies' (mental distress) that prevent her from resting.

evt_10.title: Demand cure
evt_10.description: Macbeth demands that the Doctor cure Lady Macbeth's mental illness, asking if he can 'minister to a mind diseased' and 'pluck from the memory a rooted sorrow.'

evt_11.title: Refuse treatment
evt_11.description: The Doctor replies that in this specific ailment, the patient (Lady Macbeth) must minister to herself, effectively stating the condition is beyond his medical help.

evt_12.title: Demand political diagnosis
evt_12.description: Macbeth rejects the Doctor's advice ('Throw physic to the dogs') and demands that the Doctor instead diagnose the 'disease' of Scotland (the English invasion) and purge it.

evt_13.title: Confirm threat
evt_13.description: The Doctor confirms that he has heard of the English forces, noting that Macbeth's 'royal preparation' makes the threat obvious.

evt_14.title: Express fear
evt_14.description: In an aside, the Doctor expresses his profound fear and relief at leaving Dunsinane, stating that no profit could ever draw him back.

fool-hero.justification: Retains high innate potency and physical courage ('I'll fight till from my bones my flesh be hack'd'), but his judgment is compromised by delusion and fear, leading to ineffective leadership (thanes fly from him) and emotional weakness ('sick at heart').

angel-demon.justification: A tyrannical, depraved, and dangerous ruler. He is abusive toward his servants and threatens violence against anyone who shows fear, confirming his fully corrupt moral orientation.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: He is serious and focused on military protocol (Traditionalist), but his reliance on supernatural prophecies, his erratic demands (armor on/off), and his highly creative, abusive language introduce significant unpredictability and chaos (Adventurer).

fool-hero.justification: Visibly incompetent and weak, unable to deliver a simple report without stammering and showing extreme fear ('cream-faced loon,' 'goose look'). Lacks the capability and courage required in his role.

angel-demon.justification: Humble, subservient, and harmless. He is a victim of the tyrannical environment, representing the safe, non-threatening element of the court.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Entirely predictable, focused only on fulfilling his duty as a messenger, and overwhelmed by the seriousness of the situation.

fool-hero.justification: A highly capable and loyal attendant. He is efficient in confirming reports, assisting the King with armor, and offering sensible advice ('Tis not needed yet').

angel-demon.justification: His primary moral orientation is demonic, as he is the loyal, active enabler of the tyrant Macbeth, assisting in the final, bloody defense of the corrupt regime.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: The epitome of the serious, predictable military retainer, focused entirely on protocol, duty, and the established order of the King's service.

fool-hero.justification: Highly intelligent and capable of accurate diagnosis, understanding the limits of physical medicine when dealing with mental illness ('Therein the patient / Must minister to himself'). He is purposeful in his professional role.

angel-demon.justification: Dedicated to healing and health (Angel). He is morally sound, humble, and his final aside confirms his desire to escape the corrupt court.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Strictly professional, serious, and adheres to the traditional boundaries of medical knowledge and practice. His language is formal and predictable.

evt_1.title: Encourage allies
evt_1.description: Malcolm addresses his 'Cousins' (the allied lords and leaders), expressing hope that the days of safety and peace are near.

evt_2.title: Command camouflage
evt_2.description: Malcolm issues the critical strategic order for every soldier to cut down a bough from Birnam Wood and carry it before them to conceal the size of their army, thus fulfilling the prophecy.

evt_3.title: Accept order
evt_3.description: The soldiers collectively respond, confirming that Malcolm's command regarding the boughs 'shall be done.'

evt_4.title: Report intelligence
evt_4.description: Siward reports the intelligence that Macbeth, the 'confident tyrant,' remains in Dunsinane and intends to endure a siege.

evt_5.title: Analyze enemy morale
evt_5.description: Malcolm analyzes Macbeth's strategy, noting that his remaining forces are serving only out of constraint, as their 'hearts are absent too,' justifying the allied advance.

evt_6.title: Order advance
evt_6.description: Siward concludes the strategic discussion by stating that the battle must arbitrate the outcome, and orders the army to 'advance the war.'

fool-hero.justification: Demonstrates high strategic intelligence and capability by devising the crucial plan to use Birnam Wood boughs for camouflage, ensuring tactical advantage and fulfilling the prophecy.

angel-demon.justification: The leader of the virtuous forces, focused entirely on restoring safety, order, and legitimate rule to Scotland against the tyrant Macbeth.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: While his ultimate goal is the Traditional restoration of the monarchy, the specific military tactic he employs (the moving wood) is highly creative, unconventional, and unpredictable.

fool-hero.justification: A competent and loyal lord, confirming confidence in the plan and providing necessary information (identifying the wood).

angel-demon.justification: Part of the righteous coalition fighting for justice and the restoration of the kingdom.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Acts strictly within the established military hierarchy, following orders and confirming facts.

fool-hero.justification: A seasoned general providing strategic updates and demanding decisive, practical action ('certain issue strokes must arbitrate'). Highly capable and focused on military execution.

angel-demon.justification: Leading the English forces in a moral crusade to aid the rightful Scottish king and end tyranny.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Strongly advocates for disciplined, predictable military action over 'Thoughts speculative,' representing the core of military tradition.

fool-hero.justification: A highly capable warrior and leader who urges immediate, focused, and 'industrious soldiership,' prioritizing action over speculation.

angel-demon.justification: Driven by a powerful sense of justice and vengeance against the tyrant, aligning him firmly with the Angelic pole.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Emphasizes disciplined, traditional military duty and the need for proper judgment ('just censures') based on the event.

fool-hero.justification: Demonstrate competence and discipline by immediately agreeing to execute the complex camouflage plan ('It shall be done').

angel-demon.justification: The instruments of the virtuous army, fighting for the restoration of legitimate rule.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Their role is to follow orders and maintain military discipline, which is inherently Traditionalist, even when executing an Adventurous strategy.

evt_1.title: Order defense
evt_1.description: Macbeth commands his forces to 'Hang out our banners on the outward walls,' preparing the castle for the siege.

evt_2.title: Inquire noise
evt_2.description: Macbeth hears the cry of women and asks Seyton what the noise is.

evt_3.title: Report noise source
evt_3.description: Seyton informs Macbeth that the noise is 'the cry of women.'

evt_4.title: Reflect on desensitization
evt_4.description: Macbeth reflects internally on how he has become so accustomed to horrors that he has 'almost forgot the taste of fears.'

evt_5.title: Announce death
evt_5.description: Seyton delivers the news that 'The queen, my lord, is dead' (Lady Macbeth).

evt_6.title: Reflect on mortality
evt_6.description: Macbeth delivers his famous soliloquy, reflecting on the meaninglessness of life and time ('To-morrow, and to-morrow, and to-morrow').

evt_7.title: Demand report
evt_7.description: Macbeth commands the newly entered Messenger to quickly deliver his story.

evt_8.title: Report moving wood
evt_8.description: The Messenger reports the ominous sight that 'The wood began to move' (Birnam Wood coming to Dunsinane).

evt_9.title: Threaten punishment
evt_9.description: Macbeth threatens to hang the Messenger if his report is false, but promises reciprocal treatment if it is true.

evt_10.title: Realize prophecy
evt_10.description: Macbeth realizes that the Messenger's report confirms the equivocation of the fiends, as Birnam Wood is indeed coming to Dunsinane.

evt_11.title: Order final battle
evt_11.description: Macbeth, accepting his fate, commands his forces to 'Arm, arm, and out!' and 'Ring the alarum-bell!' resolving to 'die with harness on our back.'

fool-hero.justification: Retains innate potency (Hero) as a commander and intellectual (soliloquy), but his strategic position is collapsing, his confidence is based on flawed premises, and his final state is one of despair and nihilistic failure (Fool).

angel-demon.justification: The ultimate Demon in the play at this stage; defined by 'slaughterous thoughts,' tyranny, and threats of horrific violence against subordinates.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His actions are driven by chaotic desperation and a radical break from social order (usurpation). His famous soliloquy is a highly creative, unconventional expression of nihilism.

fool-hero.justification: A competent and loyal officer, capable of performing his duties (reporting the cry, confirming the Queen's death) effectively during a crisis.

angel-demon.justification: While not actively malicious in this scene, his unwavering loyalty to the tyrannical Macbeth places him firmly within the corrupt regime (Demon).

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Strictly adheres to military protocol and the role of a loyal attendant, using formal, predictable language.

fool-hero.justification: Initially hesitant and struggling to articulate the news (Fool), but demonstrates significant courage and conviction (Hero) by standing by his unbelievable report even when threatened with immediate, agonizing death.

angel-demon.justification: Acts as an agent of truth and reality, fulfilling his duty to report what he saw, despite the danger. Represents honesty within a corrupt system.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His behavior is entirely procedural and traditional (reporting observations to his lord). The content of his message is revolutionary, but his delivery is strictly conventional.

evt_1.title: Resolve to fight
evt_1.description: Macbeth compares himself to a bear tied to a stake and resolves to fight the course, relying on the prophecy that he only fears those 'not born of woman'.

evt_2.title: Challenge identity
evt_2.description: Young Siward demands Macbeth's name, and upon hearing it, denounces him as an 'abhorred tyrant' and initiates combat to prove Macbeth a liar.

evt_3.title: Slay opponent
evt_3.description: Macbeth fights Young Siward and kills him, confirming that Young Siward was 'born of woman' and reinforcing Macbeth's false sense of invincibility.

evt_4.title: Vow vengeance
evt_4.description: Macduff enters seeking Macbeth, vowing that he will not strike at common soldiers and praying to Fortune to help him find the tyrant, lest the ghosts of his murdered family haunt him.

evt_5.title: Report military status
evt_5.description: Siward reports to Malcolm that the castle has been easily surrendered, the tyrant's forces are fighting amongst themselves, and the battle is nearly won.

evt_6.title: Direct movement
evt_6.description: Siward instructs Malcolm to enter the castle, signaling the successful occupation of the stronghold.

fool-hero.justification: Demonstrates high capability and purpose by leading the army, giving clear strategic orders (throwing down the screens, assigning battle roles), and maintaining command structure.

angel-demon.justification: The legitimate heir and leader of the righteous cause, representing virtue, safety, and the restoration of moral order against the tyrant.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: Focused on restoring the traditional monarchy and established social order. His actions are serious and follow military protocol.

fool-hero.justification: An experienced, capable general ('worthy uncle') leading the vanguard. His lines express absolute determination and fighting capability.

angel-demon.justification: A loyal, virtuous soldier fighting explicitly against the 'tyrant's power.' Represents unwavering moral commitment to the rightful cause.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: The epitome of the military Traditionalist, focused entirely on duty, order, and predictable, serious execution of battle plans.

fool-hero.justification: A highly capable warrior and leader. His command to sound the trumpets is decisive and powerful, demonstrating high potency and purpose.

angel-demon.justification: Driven by righteous vengeance and justice against Macbeth, acting as the primary agent of moral cleansing.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: While fighting for tradition, his immediate action is highly disruptive and chaotic ('clamorous harbingers of blood and death'), pushing the scene toward violent, unpredictable change (Adventurer).

fool-hero.justification: Retains physical fighting capability (Hero), but his strategic intelligence is compromised by paranoia and foolish reliance on flawed prophecies, leading to poor tactical decisions (Fool).

angel-demon.justification: The established tyrant, defined by corruption, depravity, and extreme danger to the social order.

traditionalist-adventurer.justification: His entire reign is a revolutionary break from tradition. He is fighting to maintain an illegitimate, unpredictable, and chaotic regime.

evt_1.title: Challenge
evt_1.description: Macduff enters and issues a direct challenge to Macbeth: 'Turn, hell-hound, turn!'

evt_2.title: Avoid confrontation
evt_2.description: Macbeth attempts to avoid fighting Macduff, stating his soul is already too charged with the blood of Macduff's family.

evt_3.title: Fight
evt_3.description: Macduff rejects words and initiates combat ('My voice is in my sword'). The characters engage in fighting.

evt_4.title: Reveal truth
evt_4.description: Macduff reveals the crucial truth that he was 'Untimely ripp'd' from his mother's womb, negating the prophecy that Macbeth could only be killed by one 'not of woman born'.

evt_5.title: Realize deception
evt_5.description: Macbeth realizes the 'juggling fiends' (the Witches) have deceived him, causing his 'better part of man' to be cowed.

evt_6.title: Reject surrender
evt_6.description: Despite the revelation and Macduff's taunts, Macbeth refuses to yield and resolves to fight to the death.

evt_7.title: Resume final combat
evt_7.description: Macbeth and Macduff resume fighting, leading to Macbeth's death offstage.

evt_8.title: Report death
evt_8.description: Ross reports the death of Young Siward to his father, Siward.

evt_9.title: Display trophy
evt_9.description: Macduff re-enters, displaying Macbeth's severed head, confirming the tyrant's defeat to the assembled company.

evt_10.title: Proclaim king
evt_10.description: Macduff hails Malcolm as the rightful King of Scotland.

evt_11.title: Acclaim king
evt_11.description: The assembled Thanes and Soldiers (ALL) collectively acclaim Malcolm as the new King of Scotland.

evt_12.title: Announce policy/Reward loyalty
evt_12.description: Malcolm announces his first acts as king: rewarding the Thanes by making them Earls, calling home exiles, and promising to punish the ministers of Macbeth and Lady Macbeth.
